comments.body: if you use a multiline string, then you don't need to end each line with a `\n`, which will make this much easier to read.
This is the output of the test. I'd prefer to keep it like this since it's easier to update/see diffs, etc... This format is also used in other tests.

This is how the test runner suggests edits: https://gist.github.com/blasten/e3c6ac2433e29837a77308797a2b17a9

Similar to how scuba or other baseline-like tests do it, I just copied the suggested output.

consider the following scenario:

* User has pubspec dependencies that require registrant generation and builds
* User modifies pubspec to no longer have these dependencies

Can you write a test that verifies that the generated registrant gets deleted correctly?
Here and below, just asking to confirm that these tests can't be `testWithoutContext`.
There are a few global dependencies that touches other functions as well. I managed to get these three tests to use `testWithoutContext`, but in doing so, I broke almost all the plugins test.
